SEARCH
Package math.core

Class Digit

java.lang.Object
java.lang.Number
math.core.Digit
All Implemented Interfaces:
Serializable, Comparable<Digit>
public class Digit extends Number implements Comparable<Digit>
Turns any primitive given number or a real number as string into a full notationed readable number. Digit's class presition is arbitrary, which means it can represent numbers as big as the memory allows it.

Example of use:



		Digit n = new Digit(1.23456E7);

		System.out.print(n);//12,345,600
Since:
v0.0.1
See Also:
  • Serialized Form

  • Method Details

    • toString

      public String toString()
      Implements the String format() function from extended class Notationer to print the number on a readable notation using the attributes this.integerPart, this.decimalPart and this.notation as paramethers for such function. The return values will be either negative or positive depending on the state of the attribute this.isNegative.
      Overrides:
      toString in class Object
      Returns:
      String Returns a full notationed readable number.
      Since:
      v0.0.1
      See Also:
      • Notationer.format(String, String, boolean)

    • compareTo

      public int compareTo(Digit n)
      Implements the int compareTo(Object) function from implemented class Comparable to compare the instances.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit(1.23456E7);
			Digit m = new Digit("89");

			int result = n.compareTo(m);
      The return values will be result = 1
      Specified by:
      compareTo in interface Comparable<Digit>
      Parameters:
      n - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      int Returns an x value ranging from -1<x<1 where x belongs to integers. Where 0 if both are equal, 1 if n>m and -1 if n<m.
      Since:
      v0.0.3s
      See Also:
      • Comparable.compareTo(Object)
      • Operationer.compareIntegerParts(String, String)
      • Operationer.compareDecimalParts(String, String)

      public int compareToZero()
      Compares a Digit instance to zero.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit(1);

			int result = n.compareToZero();
      The return values will be result = 1
      Returns:
      int Returns an x value ranging from -1<x<1 where x belongs to integers. Where 0 if is equals to zero, 1 if n>0 and -1 if n<0.
      Since:
      v0.0.5

    • add

      public Digit add(Digit other)
      Adds two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit("-123.45");
			Digit m = new Digit(678.9);

			Digit result = n.add(m);
      The return values will be result = 555.45
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the addition of the two instance.
      Since:
      v0.0.4
      See Also:
      • negate()

    • divide

      public Digit divide(Digit other, long presition)
      Divides two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit("7");
			Digit m = new Digit(4);

			Digit result = n.divide(m, 16);
      The return values will be result = 1.75
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      presition - Decimal presition.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the division of the two instance.
      Throws:
      ArithmeticException - if Digit other is zero.
      Since:
      v0.0.6
      See Also:
      • Notationer.trimZeros(String)
      • Operationer.division(String, String, long)

    • module

      public Digit module(Digit other)
      Gets the module between two Digit numbers logicly and sequentially.

      a mod b = |a| - |b| * FLOOR(|a|/|b|)

      The sign of the result will be the original sign from a.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit("4");
			Digit m = new Digit(2);

			Digit result = n.module(m);
      The return values will be result = 0
      Parameters:
      other - Digit instance.
      Returns:
      Digit Result from the module of the firts instance given the second instance.
      Throws:
      ArithmeticException - if Digit other is zero.
      Since:
      v0.0.8
      See Also:
      • abs()
      • subtract(Digit)
      • multiply(Digit)
      • divide(Digit, long)

    • setScale

      public Digit setScale(int scale, RoundingMode mode)
      Rounds the number given a scale and a rounding mode.

      Example of use:

      

			Digit n = new Digit("1.56");

			Digit result = n.setScale(1, RoundingMode.HALF_UP);
      The return values will be result = 1.6
      Parameters:
      scale - Decimal scale.
      mode - Rounding mode.
      Returns:
      Digit Rounded instance.
      Throws:
      ArithmeticException - if RoundingMode mode is not either a given constant for RoundingMode class or the constant is RoundingMode.UNNECESARY.
      Since:
      v0.0.8
      See Also:
      • RoundingMode
